title: Plea for swift decision on Heathrow’s third runway
text:
Save 
The head of the government-appointed Airports Commission has urged politicians to make a quick decision on expanding the country’s airport capacity in the south-east 
Speaking in a video presentation at the Runways UK conference, Sir Howard Davies insisted “an early decision was necessary”, as the UK’s expansion concerns were now a “touchstone issue around the world”. 
“Not making a decision fairly soon would be a mistake and would be difficult to present. It would then be more and more difficult as time went by to explain why people should invest in London,” Davies said. 
It came as he delivered his long-awaited report last week, which recommended a new runway at Heathrow over rival Gatwick. 
Transport secretary Patrick McLoughlin has said he will update parliament in the autumn on the government’s plans - a message reiterated by chancellor George Osborne to the conference. 
However, former Labour transport secretary Lord Andrew Adonis said he was yet to be convinced that the current government was any more serious about airport infrastructure than previous ones. 
Speaking at the conference he said there was no definitive “green light” for Heathrow; rather, it was more of a “flashing amber light at the moment”, with a lot hingeing on the involvement of David Cameron. 
Adonis also highlighted the divisions within the Conservative party, with current mayor of London Boris Johnson and potential challenger Zac Goldsmith avowedly anti-Heathrow. “The early omens are not encouraging,” he added. 
“The Conservative party is very strongly divided on this issue. It’s not going to be easy for a Conservative government to take a firm and decisive lead in the direction of Heathrow before the mayoral election.” 
Meanwhile, the commission’s report left the door slightly open for Gatwick, claiming that the West Sussex airport was “feasible”.
